content: System online! Vital signs normal. Are you with me?
Quick system check. Do you remember your security handle?
Excellent. Welcome back, ${name}. The simulation initialization was successful.
Are you ready for the simulation?
That's the spirit! You are the first to test the Pixinator 3000.
The Pixinator! My invention to digitize humans into data streams.
ALERT! ALERT! DATA BREACH DETECTED!
Bad news team. DeadPixel has bypassed our firewalls again.
Impossible! I encrypted our data with the toughest algorithms!

choices.text: Did you check for hidden data?

content: Technically true, but my encryption is mathematically sound.
Don't say that... that would be a disaster.
Encryption scrambles the message so it looks like garbage to anyone without the key.
It protects the *content* of the message. If they intercept it, they can't read it.
However, encryption makes it obvious that a secret exists. It looks suspicious.
Steganography is different. It hides the *existence* of the message entirely.
If DeadPixel is using steganography, we wouldn't even know they are communicating.
They could hide data in innocent-looking files, like images or audio.
Enough theory. To the Control Room. We need a situation report.
Listen up. The situation is critical.
DeadPixel is coordinating attacks, but we can't find their messages.
Our network scanners show zero encrypted traffic. Yet, they are synchronized.
Covert communication channels...
Exactly. How are they doing it?
We suspect digital steganography. Hiding secret data inside public files.
Their social media feeds are full of cat pictures and memes. It looks normal.
We detained Agent P., a suspected DeadPixel operative.
We secured his physical hideout. We need evidence of their methods.
${name}, search Agent P.'s room. Look for clues on how they hide data.
Dr. Voxel, stand by for digital analysis of whatever ${name} finds.
Understood!
We don't have time to waste.
Go. Now.
Dr. Voxel, your simulation is making the agent lazy.
Fascinating side effect...
Put the phone away and focus on the threat!
Deploying you to the hideout now.
I'm in Agent P.'s hideout. It looks like a standard tech workspace.
I should send evidence to Glitchwell.
There are two image files open. They look identical.
They look the same to the naked eye, but in steganography, looks deceive.
Exactly. One could be the 'Cover' and the other the 'Stego-Object'.
Don't get distracted. We are looking for hidden malware or messages.
I found a crumpled diagram in the bin.
Glitchwell is calling me.
Hey ${name}! Found anything interesting yet?
Send me a scan of that diagram.
Ah, this is the classic Steganography Model.
It shows a 'Cover Image' + 'Hidden Message' + 'Key' = 'Stego-Object'.
The 'Cover' is the innocent file (like a JPEG). The 'Message' is the payload.
The 'Key' ensures only the intended recipient can extract the message.
Without the key,  the file just looks like a normal picture.
Admin Zero needs me. Keep looking!
Wait, there's a newspaper here too. 'Cyber criminals hiding malware in memes'.
This confirms they use images to deliver malicious code.
A shelf full of cybersecurity books. Let's read the titles
'The Art of Invisibility'. It explains Steganography vs Cryptography.
Steganography hides the *fact* that communication is happening.
Cryptography hides the *meaning* of the communication.
Another book: 'Historical Secrets'.
It mentions invisible ink and microdots used in WW2 spies.
'Modern Threats': Terrorists using images to coordinate attacks covertly.
This is serious. It's not just messages; it's active coordination.
Hello ${name}! I am so relieved to hear from you. Are you done investigating?
What is the biggest threat?
Focus, agent. The cyber threat.
Correct. The hidden data.
No, we know they use crypto. The *hiding* is the issue.
Not relevant right now.
Send me the item that shows *how* they are hiding the data.
Sending item...
Receiving the diagram. Let's analyze the workflow.
This proves they use a 'Keyed Steganography' system.
The 'Carrier' is likely a JPEG or PNG image.
The 'Stego-Key' seeds the algorithm to scatter bits randomly.
This prevents us from detecting patterns easily.
If we don't know the key or the algorithm, the hidden message is safe.
We need to perform 'Steganalysis' - the art of detecting hidden data.
I need the actual files to perform Steganalysis.
Books provide theory, but we need practical evidence.
Yes, steganography is 'covered writing'.
It dates back to ancient Greece (wax tablets).
Today, we use digital media files because they are large and noisy.
An image has millions of pixels. Plenty of room to hide secrets.
Agent P. is studying this to bypass our filters.
Go back and get the actual digital files from the computer.
I have the images. Running Steganalysis tools now. What should I check first?
File sizes are identical. Good steganography doesn't change the size.
This is typical. The hidden data replaces existing bits rather than adding new ones.
Metadata (EXIF) looks clean. No hidden comments.
Sometimes amateurs hide text in the metadata comments, but Agent P. is a pro.
He is manipulating the actual visual data.
We need to look deeper. At the bits.
Analyzing the Least Significant Bits (LSB) of the pixels...
BINGO! Look at this statistical anomaly!
The LSBs are fluctuating wildly.
Digital images are made of pixels. Each pixel has color numbers (RGB).
A number like 255 is 11111111 in binary. The last '1' is the Least Significant Bit.
If I change the first bit, the color changes drastically. Visible distortion.
But if I change the last bit (LSB), the color changes by only 1 shade.
The human eye cannot see the difference between Red 254 and Red 255.
So, we can replace that last bit with our secret data without anyone seeing it.
Agent P. replaced the LSBs of this image with ASCII code!
Extracting the LSB plane now...
It's not just noise. It's text.
He didn't encrypt the message before hiding it. Rookie mistake.
Usually, you encrypt data first, THEN hide it (Stego + Crypto).
Because he was lazy,  we can read their plan.
This confirms they are using LSB Steganography.
What is the danger of this technique?
Exactly. They can chat on public forums right under our noses.
But there is a bigger risk than just chatting.
They can hide executable code (Malware) inside the image.
AND they can perform 'Data Exfiltration'.
Imagine they steal our private encryption keys.
Our firewall stops them from sending the keys out as text.
But if they hide the keys inside a holiday photo...
Would our Intrusion Detection System (IDS) stop a photo?
IDS looks for known attack signatures and suspicious traffic.
An image file looks valid to the IDS. It doesn't check the pixels.
So they can smuggle stolen data out inside images. That's Data Exfiltration.
Yes! It's called 'Stegware'.
Malware that hides its payload inside media files to avoid antivirus detection.
But there is also 'Data Exfiltration'.
They can steal our sensitive files and smuggle them out inside photos.
Our Firewall would let the photo pass.
Firewalls check headers and protocols, not pixel values.
To a firewall, it's just a cute cat picture. To us, it's a data leak.
We need to upgrade our defenses to include Steganalysis.
But first,  let's decode the message Agent P. was hiding.
I've isolated the LSBs. It forms a binary string.
Convert the binary to ASCII text.
${name}, read the hidden message. What is the target platform?
Incorrect. Check your ASCII table.
8 bits make 1 character.
The pattern is in the LSBs.
Try again.
'Face'... 'Facebook'. They are using Facebook images!
Good work. We know the channel now.
I've been monitoring their Facebook traffic all night.
It's worse than we thought. They are sending commands to botnets via image uploads.
We tracked Agent T. He is the receiver. We need to infiltrate his system.

choices.text: We can perform a DDoS attack

content: Too loud. They will just block us.
Physical access is impossible.
Think subtly.
We should beat them at their own game. Use Steganography.
Yes. We send a harmless email with a 'poisoned' image attachment.
Stegware?
Exactly. Malware hidden inside an image using steganography.
Wait. What is the goal?
We need to steal their encryption keys to decrypt their past messages.
So we need to Infiltrate -> Steal Keys -> Exfiltrate.
And we must bypass their Intrusion Detection System (IDS) and Data Leakage Protection (DLP).
Only steganography can bypass both.
${name}, you will simulate the Stegware. I'm digitizing you.
You will be the hidden payload.
Phase 1: Hiding. You must embed yourself into an image to get past their IDS.
If you are detected as code, they will delete you.
Anti-malware looks for code patterns. It ignores visual noise.
You must become the noise.
Choose a carrier file that has high entropy (randomness) so you blend in.
Phase 2: Execution. A small script (stego-loader) will extract you.
Once inside, you find the keys.
Phase 3: Exfiltration. This is the hardest part.
Their DLP scans for outgoing sensitive data (like keys).
You must hide the keys inside another image to send them back to us.
If you send the keys as text, the DLP catches you.
Hide the keys in the LSBs of a meme.
I'll monitor our 'honeypot' account for your upload.
Ready to become a Steganographic Object?
Don't get caught. If they sanitize the image, you are deleted.
Sanitization (stripping metadata or re-encoding) destroys hidden data.
Clear?
Hide in image -> Enter System -> Steal Keys -> Hide Keys in Image -> Exit.
Focus on the bits,  not me.
Digitize them, Doctor!
I am now raw data. I need to enter the DeadPixel network.
The Gateway IDS (Sentinel) is scanning incoming emails.
How do I get past the scanner?
I encrypt my code and attach myself to the email.
SCANNING... DETECTED ENCRYPTED EXECUTABLE.
Policy Violation: Unknown encrypted executables are blocked.
I cannot inspect the content, therefore it is deemed unsafe.
Quarantining attachment.
Access Denied.
GAME OVER - Cryptography draws attention.
Encryption hides contents, but not the file itself. The IDS saw a suspicious file.
Try again?
I need a 'Carrier' image. Which one is best for hiding data?
Image 1 is a simple logo with flat colors. Hiding data here creates visible noise.
This is risky, but I'll try.
Image 2 is a complex photo. High color variation hides the noise perfectly.
Image 3 is too small (Low Capacity). I cannot fit my code inside.
I'll have to compress myself dangerously.
Carrier selected. Now, where to hide my bits?
Embedding Strategy:

choices.text: At the start of the file
At the end of the file
Replace the most significant bits by me
Replace the least significant bits by me

content: I'll just tack my code onto the end of the JPG.
SCANNING... MALFORMED FILE STRUCTURE.
The End-of-File marker is followed by unauthorized data.
This is a common amateur trick.
Stripping appended data.
You have been sanitized.
Deleted.
GAME OVER - Appending data is easily detected.
Steganography must embed data *inside* the pixel values, not outside the file.
Try again.
I will replace the MSB (Most Significant Bits). This carries 50% of the color value.

choices.text: I will hide 100% in these bits to be undetectable for their anti-malware system
I will hide 100% in these bits and attach a small readable script that extracts myself

content: Injecting into MSB...
SCANNING... VISUAL ANOMALY DETECTED.
The image looks like static noise. Colors are wrong.
This is obviously a corrupted or altered file.
Blocking file.
GAME OVER.
Changing MSB destroys the image visually. You were caught.
I need to hide in the bits that change the color the least (LSB).
Try again.
I am in the network! The Agent opened the email.
The stego-loader script is extracting me from the LSBs.
I am reassembling...
Executed.
I have access.
Searching for keys...
(System Process): Searching...
SCANNING...
The script is fine, but the image is visual garbage.
The Most Significant Bits are altered. The image is destroyed.
We only accept valid images.
Quarantine.
GAME OVER.
MSB modification is too visible.
Try again.
I will hide in the LSB (Least Significant Bits). The impact on color is minimal.

choices.text: I will hide 100% in these bits to be undetectable for their anti-malware system
I will hide 100% in these bits and attach a small readable script that extracts myself

content: Wait, if I hide 100% without an extraction script
The computer will just display the image. It won't run my code.
SCANNING... IMAGE VERIFIED.
File structure valid. Visual check passed.
No known malware signature detected. You may pass.
I am inside! But... nothing is happening. I am stuck in the image.
Smart. Encrypt payload -> Hide in LSB -> Attach Loader Script.
SCANNING...
The entropy (randomness) of the LSBs is high, but the image looks normal.
Pass.
The loader script looks like a standard display tool. Approved.
I am in.
Agent T. opens the attachment...
...Loader executing...
...I am free in the system.
Phase 1 complete. Now finding the Private Keys.
Found them! file: 'private_keys.pem'.
Phase 2: Establish Command & Control before we leave.
Wrong command. Focus on the mission.
Planting the 'seed' (Listener Script).
The script monitors a public social media profile for new images.
It will scan downloadable images for hidden steganographic commands.
This allows us to control this server remotely without alerting the firewall.
Now Phase 3: Exfiltration. I need to send the keys back to HQ.

choices.text: Stego research and their private keys

content: I can't just send random photos. I need the keys.
Got the keys. Now to smuggle them out.
The DLP (Data Leakage Protection) is watching.

choices.text: Use steganography to hide myself and the information in a PDF file on the way out
Don’t do anything as the way out of the system is not protected
Use cryptography to hide the sensitive files I'm carrying

content: Halt. I am Velos, the Data Leakage Protection (DLP) system.
SCANNING OUTBOUND TRAFFIC...
You are attempting to send a file containing Private Key formatting.
Blocked. Sensitive data cannot leave the network.
Halt. I am Velos, the DLP system.
SCANNING OUTBOUND TRAFFIC...
I see a highly encrypted file. I cannot verify it is safe.
Blocked. Policy forbids unknown encrypted uploads.
GAME OVER - DLP stops obvious data theft.
I need to hide the data so Velos doesn't see it's sensitive.
Halt. I am Velos, the DLP system.
SCANNING OUTBOUND TRAFFIC...
It is a PDF file.
No text patterns matching 'Private Key' found.
Upload permitted.
Success! The keys are hidden in the PDF's layout. We have exfiltrated the data.
Signal lost...
Did we lose the agent?
The connection was severed by the antivirus.
It seems Steganography requires precision.
Mission failed.
Receiving transmission...
It's a PDF! And the structure contains the Private Keys!
Outstanding work. Restoring agent to physical form.
Welcome back. We have their keys. DeadPixel is exposed.
We learned a valuable lesson today.
Yes: Never trust a file just because it looks innocent.
We must use Steganalysis tools on all incoming media.
And disable automatic image loading in emails. Case closed.
The end.
